description: During amnesty forums, citizen testimony and technical audits reveal a critical, unfixable flaw in the BCI. Lenart Kova and Oksana Lintz begin confidential discussions on the future of digital governance.
After thorough review and urgent debate, Kova proposes a complete, irreversible shutdown of BCI scoring to avoid deeper harm. Lintz agrees, recognizing the flaw cannot be contained.
Kova and Lintz covertly execute the full deactivation of all BCI scoring and compliance subsystems, leaving minimal basic identity checks. Directorate is sidelined in the decision.
Stenograd wakes to a scoreless society. Residents improvise new routines for work, housing, and transit without automated rankings, causing shock but enabling spontaneous self-organization.

Analysis of Halden's system logs reveals he anticipated a 'total failure' scenario and embedded clues for shutdown, reframing his death as a deliberate act to expose the flaw and force the city to confront its dependence on automated control.
